Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Situation2: They occasionally tidy up visible clutter and do light cleaning in shared spaces.
Story:
I stood in the living room, mop in hand, glancing at the clock. My mother’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me how important it was to prepare the house for the upcoming family gathering. “We must keep our traditions alive,” she’d said, her eyes full of expectation. The family altar needed dusting, the special tablecloth had to be ironed, and the old porcelain dishes—used only on these occasions—waited to be washed by hand, as my grandmother always insisted.

But as a housekeeping cleaner, my job was to keep the house presentable every day, not just for special events. My employer expected spotless floors, gleaming surfaces, and no trace of dust, even in the corners no one ever looked. I’d already spent hours tidying up the visible mess, but the deep cleaning my boss demanded would take the rest of the afternoon.

I felt the pressure mounting, torn between honoring my family’s traditions and meeting the high standards of my job. My hands trembled as I tried to decide which expectation to meet first, knowing that whichever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
